ImageData.LabelName: PD-L1 binds to PD-1 and inhibits T cell killing of tumor cell
Blocking PD-L1 or PD-1 allows T cell killing of tumor cell

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Revision: Changed label in the left panel to "PD-L1 binds to PD-1 and inhibits…cell” per OCC
Added hyphens after "Anti-" for Anti-PD-L1 and Anti-PD-1

Removed labels for Antigen and T-cell receptor from right image; removed hyphen from T cell and T cell receptor labels; smoothened appearance of tumor cell; and changed title of left image to "PD-L1/PD-1 binding inhibits T cell killing of tumor cell" and right image to "Blocking PD-L1 or PD-1 allows T cell killing of tumor cell"

Made the T-Cell look a little “angrier” (a more ruffled appearance); made the tumor cell that is bound to the activated T cell look like it is dying and changed the label on it to say “Tumor cell death”; and changed titles on both panels to “explanations”: "PD-L1/PD-1 binding keeps T cell from killing tumor cell" and "Blocking PD-L1 or PD-1 allows T cell to kill tumor cell"

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Immune checkpoint inhibitor; the panel on the left shows the binding of proteins PD-L1 (on the tumor cell) to PD-1 (on the T cell), which keeps T cells from killing tumor cells in the body. Also shown are a tumor cell antigen and T cell receptor. The panel on the right shows immune checkpoint inhibitors (anti-PD-L1 and anti-PD-1) blocking the binding of PD-L1 to PD-1, which allows the T cells to kill tumor cells.

Captions.MediaCaption: Immune checkpoint inhibitor. Checkpoint proteins, such as PD-L1 on tumor cells and PD-1 on T cells, help keep immune responses in check. The binding of PD-L1 to PD-1 keeps T cells from killing tumor cells in the body (left panel). Blocking the binding of PD-L1 to PD-1 with an immune checkpoint inhibitor (anti-PD-L1 or anti-PD-1) allows the T cells to kill tumor cells (right panel).
